awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Developing a Spatial-Temporal Predictive Framework for the Drinking Water Microbiome.
awd_abstract_narration:
Every gallon of drinking water contains millions of microbes that are referred to as the drinking water microbiome. Water utilities perform extensive monitoring in the water distribution system to ensure that the drinking water microbiome remains safe as it travels from the water treatment plant to the household tap. Although these monitoring practices are designed for early detection of microbial contamination, any attempt to fix a problem identified by monitoring will be inherently reactionary. This project seeks to revolutionize the current United States drinking water monitoring system of "detect and mitigate" towards a proactive one of "predict and correct".  This project aims to develop a computer model that will allow water utilities to predict future microbial contamination events across the water distribution system, thus providing an opportunity to prevent contamination events before they occur. Integrated with the research activities will be an education program that includes training of K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students in state-of-the-art microbiome characterization and interpretation to attract them to STEM careers. The goal of this education program will be to prepare future water scientists and engineers with expertise in microbiome research and practice.

The career development plan will advance the safety and health of drinking water by integrating experimental and computational microbial ecology into drinking water microbiome research and by leveraging this research through education and outreach to engage a diverse student body in microbiome research and practice. The research goals of this project are (1) to establish a long-term observatory to monitor high-resolution drinking water microbiome dynamics in Boston?s water distribution system, (2) to develop a novel framework to apply econometric and ecological models to these dynamics, and (3) to systematically integrate the two modeling approaches for comprehensive spatial-temporal forecasting of the abundance and composition of the drinking water microbiome. The research plan combines state-of-the-art integrated analyses and novel modeling approaches to develop a quantitative predictive framework for the drinking water microbiome. This predictive framework will (1) help water utilities preemptively estimate and eliminate future drinking water microbial risks, and (2) serve as foundational knowledge for model-informed quantitative management of the drinking water microbiome. This research is integrated with an education and outreach plan designed to (1) attract and train undergraduate and graduate students in microbiome research and practice, using pedagogical approaches designed to enhance participation of students from underrepresented minority groups in STEM research, and (2) raise public awareness of the drinking-water microbiome through K-12 initiatives. The objectives will be accomplished by developing innovative microbiome-focused curricula in environmental engineering using a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) approach in collaboration with Wentworth Institute of Technology and Wellesley College and a K-12 learning activity for Boston area students through the Center for STEM Education at Northeastern University. The project will advance the shared aspirational vision of the drinking water research community and the microbiome-centric drinking water quality management community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Every liter of drinking water contains millions of microbes that are collectively referred to as the drinking water microbiome. Water utilities perform extensive treatment at drinking water treatment plants and monitoring in the water distribution system to ensure that the drinking water microbiome remains safe as it travels to the customer’s tap while primarily focusing on pathogens. There is currently very little information on the majority of the bacteria that constitute the drinking water microbiome. Further, there is very little information on factors influencing changes in the composition and abundance of the drinking water microbiome in drinking water distribution systems and building plumbing. Such data is critical to helping water utilities anticipate water quality challenges and tackle these challenges before they have an impact on public health.

 

This project included field and laboratory-based experimental work combined with molecular biology and computational biology approaches to improve our understanding of the drinking water microbiome. First, this project discovered that disinfection significantly shapes the drinking water microbiome and selects microorganisms that prefer a necrotrophic lifestyle; a necrotrophic lifestyle refers to the ability of an organism to use cellular debris from other decaying bacteria. Second, this project discovered that the presence or absence of disinfection influences the prevalence of antibiotic resistance genes in drinking water systems. Here, it is important to note that these antibiotic-resistance genes were not associated with bacterial pathogens of concern. Interestingly, this selective effect of disinfection, one of the most widely used treatment technologies, not only affects bacteria in the drinking water microbiome but also eukaryotic organisms and viruses. Specifically, this project discovered that disinfection reduces the diversity of both eukaryotes and viruses in the drinking water distribution system. The reduction in diversity of bacteria, eukaryotes, and viruses in disinfected drinking water systems is not only systematic but also selects for specific organisms. For example, by monitoring two large drinking water systems that both utilize two disinfectants (i.e., chlorine and chloramine) in different regions of the distribution system, this project was able to show that chlorine and chloramine shape the drinking water microbiome predictably despite seasonal variations. Similarly, by analyzing data from drinking water systems globally, this project showed that disinfection selects for very few bacterial genera in drinking water. In fact, one specific bacterial species is present in most disinfected drinking water systems globally. While previous research had detected this bacterial species, it had been mischaracterized as belonging to a well-known bacterial family. This globally distributed bacterial species of importance to drinking water quality is indeed a novelty bacterial species and its genome encodes the potential for high levels of disinfection resistance. The research team proposed a name for this species Raskinella chloraquaticus, which has been approved by taxonomy experts and is now incorporated into public databases. Finally, the research team also discovered that while treatment and distribution practices shape the drinking water microbiome, bacterial species and strains within bacterial species exhibit preferences based on characteristics of building plumbing. Specifically, even closely related bacterial strains show preferences for large buildings (e.g., commercial buildings) or small buildings (i.e., residential households) likely driven by the size of the building’s plumbing and water usage patterns. The above-outlined discoveries significantly advance our ability to manage the drinking water microbiome and advance the safety of drinking water.

 

This project also created important community resources that will significantly advance the fields of drinking water and environmental microbiology. Specifically, the research team developed an open-source and open-access drinking water genome database; the first of its kind. The team also developed a low-cost autonomous microscope for microbial monitoring and should facilitate broad-scale and distributed microbial monitoring. This project also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate researchers, engaged industry collaborators, and contributed to the development of educational modules that advance the field of drinking water microbiology and engineering. Specifically, this project directly contributed to the training of three M.S. students, three Ph.D. researchers, and 25 undergraduate researchers, most of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM. Further, support from this project enabled the graduate students to attend and present their work conferences. The undergraduate researchers were trained in a range of laboratory techniques that are routine in the field of environmental biotechnology and microbiology, along with training in state-of-the-art molecular and computational biology techniques. Outcomes of this research were integrated into educational modules taught at Northeastern University and Georgia Institute of Technology,  as well as virtually delivered to graduate students as part of their graduate curriculum at national and international universities and also led to the development of a new course on Microbiome Engineering,
